dt: {bc}a usually rectangular-shaped bag (as of paper, burlap, or canvas)
{bc}a fixed amount of a commodity used as a unit of measure
{bc}a short usually loose-fitting coat for women and children
{bc}an instance of sacking the quarterback in football

et: Middle English {it}sak{/it} bag, sackcloth, from Old English {it}sacc{/it}, from Latin {it}saccus{/it} bag & Late Latin {it}saccus{/it} sackcloth, both from Greek {it}sakkos{/it} bag, sackcloth, of Semitic origin; akin to Hebrew {it}śaq{/it} bag, sackcloth
shortdef: a usually rectangular-shaped bag (as of paper, burlap, or canvas)
the amount contained in a sack; especially : a fixed amount of a commodity used as a unit of measure

dt: {bc}to put in or as if in a sack
{bc}to tackle (the quarterback) behind the line of scrimmage in football

shortdef: to put in or as if in a sack
to tackle (the quarterback) behind the line of scrimmage in football

dt: {bc}any of several white wines imported to England from Spain and the Canary Islands during the 16th and 17th centuries

et: modification of Middle French {it}sec{/it} dry, from Latin {it}siccus{/it}; probably akin to Old High German {it}sīhan{/it} to filter, Sanskrit {it}siñcati{/it} he pours
shortdef: any of several white wines imported to England from Spain and the Canary Islands during the 16th and 17th centuries

dt: {bc}to plunder (a place, such as a town) especially after capture

pt: {sc}ravage{/sc} {sc}devastate{/sc} {sc}waste{/sc} {sc}sack{/sc} {sc}pillage{/sc} {sc}despoil{/sc} mean to lay waste by plundering or destroying. {sc}ravage{/sc} implies violent often cumulative depredation and destruction.
{sc}devastate{/sc} implies the complete ruin and desolation of a wide area.
{sc}waste{/sc} may imply producing the same result by a slow process rather than sudden and violent action.

pt.t: years of drought had {it}wasted{/it} the area

pt: {sc}sack{/sc} implies carrying off all valuable possessions from a place.
{sc}pillage{/sc} implies ruthless plundering at will but without the completeness suggested by {sc}sack{/sc}.
{sc}despoil{/sc} applies to looting or robbing without suggesting accompanying destruction.

shortdef: to plunder (a place, such as a town) especially after capture

et: Middle French {it}sac{/it}, from Old Italian {it}sacco{/it}, literally, bag, from Latin {it}saccus{/it}
shortdef: the plundering of a captured town

dt: {bc}a man's jacket with a straight back

shortdef: a man's jacket with a straight back
to go to bed : go to sleep

dt: {bc}a jumping race in which each contestant's legs are enclosed in a sack

shortdef: a jumping race in which each contestant's legs are enclosed in a sack

dt: {bc}a sack of a coarse material (such as burlap)

et: alteration of {it}crocus sack, crocus bag{/it}, of unknown origin
shortdef: a sack of a coarse material (such as burlap)

dt.t: … a {wi}sad sack{/wi} so unlucky in love that when his girlfriend splits, his family sides with her.
